instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-2936 question
threads.message: hello masters I have a 820-2936 that needs a u5400 , I have 2 donorboards but booth don't have it any more , my question is :can I use U5410 instead? because that one is present on my donors. what do you think?

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-2936 question
threads.message: INA213 in an SC70 package is an INA213 in an SC70 package regardless of what it is used for.

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-2936 question

I still think this is SMC_LID issue. Leave the BIL disconnected and try again. Boot from something that has OSX on it, not some PC crap. 
At the moment you do get LCD/BKL after it boots to some PC crap?

threads.message: Ok im going to update my findings , I when and check Q9706 and on pins 3 and 4 I have 12.6v , what this mean that voltage divider is not working? for [SIZE=14px][FONT=Courier][FONT=Courier]LCDBKLT_EN_DIV what voltage I suppose to have? [/FONT][/FONT][/SIZE][FONT=Courier][SIZE=1][FONT=Courier][SIZE=1][SIZE=14px]R9788[/SIZE] [SIZE=18px][SIZE=16px]and r9789 match schematic and c9782 has no continuity on its pins , [/SIZE][/SIZE][SIZE=16px]PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR have no power.[/SIZE][/SIZE][/FONT][/SIZE][/FONT]

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-2936 question
threads.message: Well I think I just start to destroy and sodomize the board , I remove Q9706 and run a wire from pin 4 to [SIZE=16px][FONT=Courier New]PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR [/FONT][/SIZE]to check if that will give me the backlight back , but when I power the machine I see light coming from the lcd for less that 1 second all gets white and then go back to be all dark and light don't come back and does the same each time I power on.

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-2936 question
threads.message:
The LCD is not recognized! Doing some stupid shit is NOT going to magically fix this.
PP3V3_S0, DDC_CLK and DDC_DATA are involved in this. Seeing that you said there was corrosion on the LCD connector it is probably fucked.

If diode mode on all these 3 signals show something the it is probably the connector/cable

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-2936 question
threads.message:
PP3V3_S0                        = .353
LVDS_DDC_CLK             = .589
LVDS_DDC_DATA          = .633

I did read with cable connected

without cable:

LVDS_DDC_DATA          = .678
LVDS_DDC_CLK             = .678
PP3V3_S0                        = .353



I will try to do less stupid things :P I will solder back Q9706 nad remove the wire.

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-2936 question
threads.message: That seems ok, but you never know with 3V_S0. If there is corrosion on the connector at any point I would replace it. Have you also tried another LCD assembly? Are you sure SMC_LID is high?

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-2936 question

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-2936 question
threads.message: Take a LCD cable and measure if pin 4 6 and 7 actually come out the other side of the cable. Connector could be bad inside.

threads.message:

[url=http://postimg.org/image/ugj9qm3m9/][img]http://s32.postimg.org/ugj9qm3m9/20160428_122606.jpg[/img][/url]

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-2936 question
threads.message: One of the LVDS lines is missing or shorted together or GND. Again take an LCD cable and measure all LVDS lines to the other side. Also check if pins are shorted together. L9080 is also infamous for being damaged, measure lines after it on diode mode all LVDS line should be the same value.

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-2936 question
threads.message: all LVDS lines are .654 some .664 with cable connected I replace L9080 and problem still remain

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-2936 question
threads.message:
You don't replace L9080 if it measures fine! Measure again with a separate cable and measure on LCD end.
Also that .654 MUST go down on all lines when you plug in an LCD!

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-2936 question

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-2936 question
threads.message: hello masters , since I have no cable I decide to run ASD just to see if something else is wrong and take care of that , and program find VPOR -- PBUS fail , how I can find witch one is it on the board?

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-2936 question
threads.message:
[QUOTE="pcfriends, post: 2156"]hello masters , since I have no cable I decide to run ASD just to see if something else is wrong and take care of that , and program find VPOR -- PBUS fail , how I can find witch one is it on the board?[/QUOTE]

Schematics, if you type Vp0R you will see it. Notice... that is not "O" is 0 (zero)
IF not try typing [FONT=Courier]PBUS Voltage Sense Enable & Filter
Then check in board view
Visual inspection on resistors, if they look like C&B, replace them[/FONT]

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-2936 question
threads.message: Corrosion around Q5300, usually pin 4 is gone or the resistors next to it.

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-2936 question

threads.title: [SOLVED]820-2936 question
threads.message: hello masters , I finally was able to fix this board , I solder a new lcd conector and now is working fine thank you!
